I dont think there is an option to show all context, but you can      
check out my patch (suggestion) on how to get a better                
output.  The patch tries to find the best position in the string      
around the difference in order to minimize the context but            
still have a context. The best position is determined by ',' ';' and  
 ' '. or if none of those are found 15 characters before and after.   
                                                                      
Enough said, check it out at:                                         
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=657593&group_
id=15278&atid=315278                                                  
or at:                                                                
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?group_id=15278&atid=315278            
                                                                      
Just download the JUnit source and replace ComparisonFailure          
with mine, and you will have a better output.                         
And if you find improvements, please let me know!!                    
                                                                      
//Erik                                                                
> Is there an option in junit 3.8.1 to get context from getMessage in 
> junit.framework.ComparisonFailure, more similar to the pre-3.8      
> situation?     I haven't found one.  I don't at all like the new    
> output format, with "..." replacing initial and final parts of the  
> text that are equal between the "expected" and "found" values.      
> There's no context at all!  This makes it take more time or effort  
to                                                                    
> identify the offending input text, and the offending characters     
within                                                                
> the offending text.  What if the test complains about <...X...> and 
I                                                                     
> have 20 Xes in my text?  Now I can't tell which one indicates the   
> problem.  Also, I can no longer use the full text as a quick clue to
> the particular test that's complaining.  It would already be an     
> improvement to include, say, 10 characters of context on either side
> of the part that differs between the "expected" and "found" values. 
> It would be even better if users could select how much context they 
> get, to satisfy both those who prefer getting all context over      
getting                                                               
> none (like myself) and those who prefer getting none over getting   
all                                                                   
> (like the people who recommended the use of the current ...         
mechanism).
